questions.question: A chronic alcoholic developed cirrhosis of the liver. Which is the principal cell type involvedin scar deposition in this condition?
questions.explanation: The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in cirrhosis of the liver is the hepatic stellatecell or Ito cell.Hepatic stellate cells deposit primarily type I and type III collagen in the lobule and cause fibrosis.In their quiescent form, these cells store lipids and vitamin A.

questions.question: 909Histopathological examination of liver biopsy reveals steatosis. Which of the followingconditions is least likely to cause this change?

options.B: Hepatitis C infectionWilson's diseased) Protein malnutritionQuestion 5:Which of the following conditions causes macrovesicular steatosis of liver?a) Reye syndromeb) Obesity

questions.explanation: Steatosis or fatty change of liver is not seen in hepatitis B infections.Steatosis is the abnormal accumulation of triglycerides within a cell due to impaired lipidmetabolism. In the liver, pathological steatosis is defined as fatty change involving >5% ofhepatocytes. In the histologic sections, they appear as empty vacuoles within the hepatocyte920cytoplasm.Hepatitis C genotype 3 is reported to cause periportal steatosis. It is due to its association withmetabolic syndrome and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).In Wilson's disease, there is focal hepatocyte necrosis and steatosis due to toxic injury by theexcess copper.In protein malnutrition, fatty liver results from the reduced synthesis of the carrier proteincomponent of lipoproteins.

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl, with a history of URTI, now presents with severe vomiting, lethargy, andaltered mental status. You are suspecting Reye's syndrome. Which of the following liverbiopsy findings will confirm your diagnosis?

options.C: Portal tract edema and perisinusoidal fibrosis
options.D: Cirrhosis and periportal eosinophilic inclusion bodies

questions.explanation: The liver biopsy in Reye's syndrome will show marked microvesicular steatosis.Reye's syndrome is an acute illness, encountered exclusively in children <15 years. Its onsetusually follows upper respiratory tract infections. The actual cause is unknown, although viralagents and salicylates (aspirin) have been implicated.Pathogenesis behind this condition is generalized mitochondrial dysfunction with structural andfunctional alterations of mitochondria in the liver, brain, and muscle. Liver is enlarged butjaundice is absent or minimum. It is characterized by clinical features such as:•Vomiting•Signs of progressive CNS damage••Signs of hepatic injuryHypoglycemiaExtensive accumulation of fat droplets within hepatocytes (microvesicular steatosis) can be seenin histopathology. Extra-hepatic changes include fatty changes of renal tubular cells, cerebraledema, and neuronal degeneration of the brain.The image given below shows microvesicular steatosis of liver.922MicrovesicularNote: Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children, except in the treatment of Kawasaki diseaseand juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

questions.question: Histopathological examination of liver biopsy in a patient with jaundice shows the followingfinding. Which of the following conditions is least likely in this patient?910
questions.explanation: The marked structure in the image is Mallory hyaline body which is not seen in primary sclerosingcholangitis. In this condition, onion skin fibrosis is seen.Mallory hyaline bodies (Mallory-Denk bodies) are usually present as clumped, amorphous,eosinophilic material in ballooned hepatocytes. They are made up of cytokeratin 8 and cytokeratin18. They have a twisted rope-like appearance. On trichrome stain, they appear green/darkbrown. They are seen in:• Alcoholic liver disease• Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease• Wilson's disease•Hepatocellular carcinoma•Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency•Primary biliary cholangitis (formerly called primary biliary cirrhosis)• Indian childhood cirrhosisThe image given below shows Mallory hyaline bodies.923Mallory hyaline bodiesMallory hyaline bodiesMalloryhyaline bodies

questions.question: Which of the following causes Laennec cirrhosis?
questions.explanation: Laennec cirrhosis is the classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in end-stage alcoholic liver disease.There are three distinctive, overlapping forms of alcoholic liver injury:• Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver)•Fatty change completely reversible if there is abstention from further intake of alcohol-• Starts in centrilobular area• Alcoholic (steato) hepatitis• Ballooning degeneration and necrosis• Mallory-Denk bodies924•Neutrophilic reaction• Alcoholic steatofibrosis•• Perisinusoidal fibrosis and sclerosis of the central vein• Diffuse nodularity of liver surface•Micronodular/ Laennec cirrhosis• Irreversible

questions.question: What is the most common hepatotoxin causing acute liver failure?
questions.explanation: The most common hepatotoxin causing acute liver failure is acetaminophen.Acetaminophen itself is not toxic. The toxic metabolite produced by the cytochrome P-450 systemin zone 3 hepatocytes causes hepatocellular necrosis.The most common hepatotoxin causing chronic liver failure is alcohol.

questions.question: Which of the following does not cause chronic infection?
questions.explanation: Hepatitis A does not cause chronic infection. It is usually a benign, self-limited disease.Hepatitis B, C, and D can cause chronic infection. Hepatitis E causes chronic infection only inimmunocompromised individuals, not in immunocompetent.

questions.question: There is an outbreak of hepatitis A infection in a college hostel. Which of the following is falseabout this infection?

options.A: It does not cause hepatocellular carcinoma
options.C: Liver failure is not a complication

questions.explanation: Hepatitis A virus (HAV) can cause acute hepatic failure in a few patients. However, it does notcause chronic hepatitis or a carrier state.HAV is a usually benign, self-limited disease, with an incubation period of 15-50 days (2-6weeks).HAV is spread by feco-oral route and is shed in the stool for 2 to 3 weeks before and 1 week afterthe onset of jaundice. It can also spread by sexual route. Diagnosis is by the detection of serumIgM anti HAV.Since it does not progress to chronic infection, it does not cause hepatocellular carcinoma. Thefatality rate associated with HAV is only about 0.1-0.3%.928

questions.question: Which among the following is the most common cause of sporadic acute hepatitis in India?
questions.explanation: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection accounts for most of the cases of sporadic acute hepatitis inIndia. It exceeds the frequency of hepatitis A virus infection.A feature of HEV infection is the high mortality rate among pregnant women, approaching 20%.

questions.question: A 53-year-old man who has a history of chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed to havehepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of thiscondition?
questions.explanation: HBx protein has been implicated in the pathogenesis of hepatocellular carcinoma in hepatitis Bvirus (HBV) infection. HBx protein is involved in the intracellular regulation of virusreplication, transcription, and signal transduction.Option A: HBsAg (surface antigen) indicates current hepatitis B infection.Option B: HBeAg (precore antigen) is an indicator of active viral replication. It is a qualitativemarker of infectivity.Option C: HBV DNA polymerase is an indicator of active viral replication. It is a quantitativemarker of infectivity.

questions.question: Which of the following serological markers can be used to diagnose hepatitis B infectionduring the window period?
questions.explanation: During the window period of hepatitis B, the serologic diagnosis can be made by the detection ofIgM anti-HBc antibody.The window period of hepatitis B refers to the time between the disappearance of the HBsAgantigen and appearance of Anti-HBs antibody.The window period for a test designed to detect a specific disease is the time between the firstinfection and when the test can reliably detect that infection.

questions.question: In a patient who is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, what does declining IgM anti-HBc andrising total anti-HBc indicate?
questions.explanation: In patients who are both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, declining IgM anti-HBc and rising totalanti-HBc are indicative of chronic infective hepatitis.Anti-HBc IgM antibody signifies acute infection/window period, whereas, the presence of IgGanti-HBc indicates chronic infection. However, there is no test available to directly detect the IgGanti-HBC. Over a period of months, the IgM anti-HBc antibodies are replaced by the IgG anti-HBcantibodies. Thus a decline of IgM antibodies in the presence of rising total anti-HBC indicates thatthe IgM is being converted to IgG and thus the infection is chronic.HBeAg, HBV-DNA, and DNA polymerase appear in serum soon after HBsAg, and all signify activeviral replication.929Occasionally, mutated strains of HBV emerge that do not produce HBeAg but arereplication-competent and express HBcAg.

questions.question: A patient with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse turns out to be HBsAg positive.Which of the following is the best predictor for development of chronic disease?
questions.explanation: The age at the time of infection is the best predictor of chronicity. Younger the age at the time ofhepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, higher the probability of chronicity.Other predictors in the development of chronic disease:⚫ comorbid conditions (including exposure to other infectious agents)⚫ host immunity••Presentations of hepatitis B infection:Asymptomatic - 65%• Non-specific symptoms -25%• Chronic disease - 5-10%• Acute fulminant liver disease - 0.1-0.5%

questions.question: An IV drug abuser has been found to be seropositive for HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgM.Which of the following is least likely to be seen in the liver biopsy of such patients?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hepatitis B infection. Ground-glass hepatocytesare not seen in the liver biopsy of such patients.Histopathological findings in acute hepatits are:• Ballooning degeneration - due to inflammation• Portal or lobular inflammatory infiltration - lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils• Necrosis•⚫ Confluent necrosis - group of hepatocytes.• Panlobular or panacinar necrosis - entire lobule•Bridging necrosis (in severe cases) - connecting vascular structuresGround-glass appearance of hepatocytes is due to the endoplasmic reticulum which is swollenwith HBsAg accumulation. It is a diagnostic hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection.The image given below shows ground glass hepatocytes in the liver biopsy.930Chronic hepatitis B infectionChronic hepatitis B infectionGround glasshepatocytes

questions.question: A man with a history of intranasal cocaine abuse is at most risk for which of the followinginfections?
questions.explanation: Intranasal cocaine abuse is a risk factor for hepatitis C.Contaminated implements (like straws used to inhale cocaine) inserted into the nasal cavity mightcome into contact with hepatitis C virus (HCV)-infected mucus or blood. This might then betransmitted to a susceptible individual while sharing the same implements.Transmission of hepatitis C infection:•Intravenous drug abuse (54%) - Most common• Multiple sex partners•Needle-stick injury•Multiple contacts with a person with hepatitis C virus infection931• Employment in medical or dental fields• Blood transfusion•• Perinatal - major route of infection in children

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common clinical course in patients diagnosed withhepatitis C infection?
questions.explanation: The most common clinical course seen in hepatitis C infection is chronic carrier state.Acute clinical illness is often asymptomatic/mild with a high rate of conversion to chronichepatitis (~85%).Clinical course of Hepatitis CMADecompensatedcirrhosisAcute HCV infection85% risk of developingChronic infection20% risk over 20 yearsCirrhosisOMARROWHepatocellularcarcinoma

questions.question: Which genotype of hepatitis C virus is associated with metabolic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) genotype 3 is associated with metabolic syndrome.HCV can give rise to insulin resistance and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

questions.question: A 40-year-old male patient with chronic hepatitis B infection comes for a follow-up visit.Which of the following is not a histopathological feature of the liver in such cases?
questions.explanation: Ballooning degeneration is not associated with chronic hepatitis. It is seen in acute hepatitis.Histopathological findings in chronic viral hepatitis are:••Portal lymphocytic/ lymphoplasmacytic inflammation• Interface activity - inflammatory cells cross the limiting plate and cause periportal hepatocyteinjury• Portal, periportal, and portoportal bridging fibrosis932Specific findings in viral hepatitis:-•Hepatitis B ground glass hepatocytes•• Hepatitis C - lymphoid aggregates and steatosis

questions.question: In patients with liver failure, which of the following tests is not used to evaluate the syntheticfunction of hepatocytes?915

options.B: APTTSerum albumind) Serum alkaline phosphataseQuestion 26:Which of the following is not seen in the histopathological examination of the liver in patientswith malaria?a) Mononuclear portal infiltrateb) Macronodular cirrhosis

questions.explanation: Serum alkaline phosphatase is used to evaluate biliary excretory function. It is not used toevaluate the synthetic function of hepatocytes.Serum ammonia, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and serum albumin are used toevaluate hepatic synthetic function.Prothrombin time (PT), aPTT and serum ammonia levels are increased in liver failure, whereasserum albumin level is decreased.

questions.question: Identify the incorrect match.
questions.explanation: Councilman bodies are apoptotic hepatocytes seen in acute hepatitis and yellow fever.Option A: Mallory-Denk bodies are eosinophilic materials made of keratin intermediatefilaments. questions.question: A patient with ascites, melena, and splenomegaly is diagnosed with portal hypertension.Which of the following is not an intrahepatic cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Obstructive portal vein thrombosis is the prehepatic cause of portal hypertension.Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cirrhosis, and schistosomiasis are intrahepatic causes of portalhypertension. The most dominant cause is cirrhosis.

questions.question: 916Which of the following is not a feature of liver histology in patients with non-cirrhotic portalfibrosis?

options.B: Thrombosis of the medium and small portal vein branches

questions.explanation: Bridging fibrosis is not seen in non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis. In this condition, there is periportaland perisinusoidal fibrosis. The fibrous septa end blindly in the lobule and do not bridge withother portal tracts, unlike those seen in cirrhosis.Idiopathic non-cirrhotic portal hypertension (INCPH) is a rare disease characterized byintrahepatic portal hypertension in the absence of cirrhosis or other causes of liver disease andsplanchnic venous thrombosis.A liver biopsy is essential in making a diagnosis of INCPH. The features observed are as follows:•⚫ Luminal narrowing or obliteration of portal vein branches• Micronodular transformation• Sinusoidal dilatation with formation of mega sinusoids• Periportal and perisinusoidal fibrosis
